newsitem.title: JAPAN: Japan says Indonesia car policy may be quad issue.
newsitem.headline: Japan says Indonesia car policy may be quad issue.

text.p: Indonesia's national car policy may be discussed in four-way trade talks in Seattle this weekend, even though it is not on the formal agenda, Japan's Trade Minister Shunpei Tsukahara said on Friday.
Tsukahara was due to leave for Seattle later on Friday for twice-yearly talks on global trade and investment with his U.S., European Union (EU) and Canadian counterparts.

"The issue of Indonesia's car policy may be raised at my bilateral meeting with (EU Trade Commissioner Sir Leon) Brittan and it may be raised at lunch with the others," Tsukahara told a news conference.
Indonesia's national car plan, announced earlier this year, has come under fire from Japan, the United States and the EU as a violation of world trade rules.
In February, Indonesia gave special tax and tariff breaks to PT Putra Timor Nasional to make a "national car" in partnership with Kia Motors Corp of South Korea.
The Indonesia firm is controlled by President Suharto's youngest son, Hutomo Mandala Putra.

Tokyo argues that Jakarta's scrapping of import duties on components and exemption of a luxury sales tax for local carmakers able to meet local content and other requirements breached World Trade Organisation rules.
Tsukahara said he might also discuss with Brittan a recent U.S.-Japan agreement on microchip trade.

Tsukahara said, however, that he had no plan to bring up a dispute over Washington's charges of unfair trade barriers in Japan's photo film market with U.S. Trade Representative Charlene Barshefsky. The United States took its complaint to the WTO earlier this year.
The quadrilateral meeting is expected to set the scene for the first WTO ministerial gathering in Singapore in December.
